awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Individualized Cognitive Training Interventions Based on a Multifaceted Theory of Working Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Working memory is the ability to actively maintain, manipulate, and retrieve relevant information during everyday tasks. An individual's working memory functioning is strongly and positively related to important outcomes such as intelligence, reading comprehension, mathematic proficiency, and resistance to distraction. An important question is what specific cognitive processes can explain why working memory is so critical for these diverse aspects of behavior. A related question is whether increasing a person's working memory functioning via computerized memory exercises will lead to improvements not just in working memory but also in related outcomes, such as intelligence and reading comprehension. This research project will provide the foundation for new theoretical perspectives about working memory that have the potential to drastically alter the future of cognitive training research and commercialization. The information gained via this project comes at a critical juncture, as the public, K-12, and medical use of computerized cognitive training is increasing, along with recent estimates of billions of US dollars spent on such computerized training. The investigators will provide workshops and lectures to students, faculty, community members, and K-12 teachers and administrators, both in-person and via Internet-based materials. In addition, the project will provide a variety of hands-on research opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.

The project will investigate a novel approach to cognitive training, by first identifying specific working memory strengths and weaknesses in a large sample of young adults, and then developing specific cognitive training exercises that target an individual's working memory functioning. This approach differs from the typical one-size-fits-all method of cognitive training that does not consider the individual's particular cognitive profile. Before and after training, participants will complete various cognitive tests designed to assess whether the training leads to very specific improvements (i.e., outcomes similar to the training program) or broader improvements (i.e., intelligence, reading comprehension). The design of the project will provide the strongest and clearest evidence yet about the potential utility of working memory training to produce meaningful changes in working memory, intelligence, and reading comprehension.

por.por_cntn:
Psychologists, educators, and clinicians use the concept of working memory to refer to the ability to actively maintain, manipulate, and retrieve relevant information. People use working memory when they solve arithmetic problems in their head, when they read multiple sentences and need to remember what a pronoun refers to from an earlier sentence, and when they are walking to a novel location in a city while carrying on a conversation. In school, individuals with lower working memory functioning have more difficulty following instructions, and in the military, individuals with higher working memory functioning are more likely to successfully complete air-traffic control training. An important question is what specific cognitive processes can explain why working memory is so critical for these diverse aspects of behavior. Many theories have tried to explain working memory as one thing, whether that be ?attention?, ?memory retrieval?, or ?capacity?. However, our account views working memory as a multifaceted one. In a study with nearly 1,000 young adult participants, our results from this project show that individuals that exhibit higher or lower levels of working memory functioning differ on multiple cognitive processes. This has not just important theoretical consequences, but is also important from an applied perspective. Understanding more precisely why individuals lower in working memory functioning struggle in certain contexts, such as reading comprehension, can help inform more tailored and individualized cognitive training programs. In the second major goal of our project, we followed the best practices for conducting cognitive training intervention studies. A large sample of participants completed 15 sessions of one of five challenging, adaptive cognitive training methods to target a specific cognitive process that was measured in study one. Before and after the cognitive training, participants also completed various tests designed to assess whether the training leads to very specific improvements (i.e., outcomes similar to the training program) or broader improvements (i.e., intelligence, reading comprehension). While analyses of the training data continue, the results thus far suggest that although participants can substantially improve on the training tasks themselves, and that their specific working memory profile before training affects the amount of training improvement, transfer to other outcomes such as reading comprehension is limited.
